ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write plays, and I learned how to talk about plays and analyze them as distinct forms of artwork.

I learned so much about playwriting, and was able to gain so much valuable skills even though I had no prior experience with playwriting or theater! I feel able to creatively envision worlds, and have a better idea of how to get started when I want to write.
I learned how to navigate questions of gender and queerness through playwriting and continued to develop my storytelling voice and style.
How to write plays and think outside of societal norms
Honed the craft of playwriting with special attention to writing plays that dissect gender and queerness.

I learned to think critically about gender in the plays we read, and about how different trans playwrights today use the form of playwriting itself to interrogate the gender binary. I also became a much more experienced writer, thanks to the weekly assignments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class was a great writer's workshop: for the first half of the semester, we did writing exercises that allowed us to build our skills, and then apply them in the second half. It worked well, and I felt like I got a lot out of it. I wish, though, we had more time to discuss the readings. I think this class would work better if we had one day a week that was discussing the readings, and then one day of the week dedicated to student feedback (which, at the midsemester point, would flip to all student feedback).
I think greater and earlier communication would be helpful in having a better idea about next steps and where we stand in the class grade-wise.

One of the greatest strengths of this course was the supportive and fun classroom environment. I felt very safe to experiment in my writing and loved reading my classmates' incredible work. The workshop format was encouraging and always generated interesting discussion.
Great assignments and class structure - challenging without being overwhelming to new writers.

The reading list for this course is absolutely fantastic, and the writing prompts for each week gave me a ton of creative inspiration and freedom. I think the structure of the course could be changed a bit, since doing critiques every week was sort of tiring (though that was a huge part of the course that helped me grow as a writer).
The strength of this course is the professor and the community of writers that is created within it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This was my favorite class I've taken at Yale, so far. The syllabus was superb, the writing exercises were generative, and Professor Kaufman did a great job at creating a safe, positive environment for sharing my writing. I cannot recommend it enough.
100%  I've never learned or felt like my skills were developed as much as I have in any other class at Yale.
Yes!

Yes. It was great to explore these questions about gender in a safe and supportive space, to be introduced to so many plays by trans and non-binary authors, and feel free to experiment with new ideas in my writing.
Yes!! Safe space to grow and experiment as a writer
yes! you will get such good feedback on writing, read really cool plays, and get to be a part of a special community of playwrites on campus

Absolutely. Professor Kaufman is incredible, and every assigned reading and class discussion was interesting. I also improved my own writing significantly and had the chance to write a one-act play, which isn't something I ever thought I would be able to do.
Absolutely! Nowhere else can you find a community of queer/trans writers at college. This was a beautiful experience.
